iati-activity.description: The project aims to increase climate change resilience at landscape level by applying the principles of ecosystem based adaptation.

document-link.title: Mid-term evaluation: Ecosystem based adaptation project

iati-activity.title: Ecosystem-based adaptation
iati-activity.description: The project objective is to maintain the water provisioning services supplied by mountain and steppe ecosystems by internalizing climate change risks within land and water resource management regimes.

iati-activity.title: Managed Resource Protected Area
iati-activity.description: Network of Managed Resource Protected Area

iati-activity.title: Managed Resource Protected Are
iati-activity.description: "Mongolia's Network of Managed Resource Protected Areas" is to catalyze the strategic expansion of Mongolia's Protected area system through establishment of a network of community conservation area covering under-represented terrestrial ecosystems.

result.title: Objective
result.description: Catalyze the strategic expansion of Mongolia’s PA system through establishment of a network of community conservation areas covering under-represented terrestrial ecosystems.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Hectares within the total protected area system, including community conservation areas

baseline.comment: Total LPA (without community managed areas) is 16 Mln. ha, but not included in the NPA System.

actual.comment: Total LPA (without community managed areas) was found to be 20.5 million ha based on the recent in-depth survey on the LPA coverage. Although it appears that the end of project target has already been reached, this new figure is largely as a result of more accurate investigation on the LPA coverage which tends to be fluid (as local authority can gazette and de-gazette or the set period for protection can expire) . 20.5 million ha includes 3 new LPAs and extension of Gulzat LPA, which were facilitate directly by the project, accounting for 0.25 million ha in total. However LPA are not yet recognized as part of the national PA system. With the approval of the revised SPA Law in the current version, the LPAs will be officially part of the PA system.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Hectares of seven under-represented ecosystems within total protected areas system, including community conservation areas

baseline.comment: Total area of under-represented ecosystems is 102 Mln. ha.

actual.comment: Hectares of seven under-represented ecosystems within total protected areas system, including community conservation areas, is 102 million ha. This is according to a more accurate assessment of the LPA coverage supported by the project as above.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Establishment of new PA category for strategic PA expansion

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Specific NPA legislation amended and/or new regulation adopted to establish and guide effective management of community conservation areas

baseline.comment: 0 No national law and/or regulation adopted as described

target.comment: 1 national law and/or regulation adopted as described

actual.comment:
1.Regulation on "Taking land under local protection" (2000) is currently under revision towards setting up clear criteria and processes for LPAs, including CCAs.
2.As a result of 1st National Forum for CBOs organized by MEGDT jointly with all donor organizations, it’s been issued an Order #07 of Parliament Standing Committee on Agriculture and Environment dated July 09, 2015 towards undertaking required actions and allocation of state budget to strengthen the governance and management of CCAs and build capacity of CBOs throughout the country.
3.Working group for drafting revised laws of Special Protected Area and Buffer Zone was re- established due to recently re-structured Ministry of Environment, Green Development &Tourism (MEGDT). The working group has refined the revised drafts through series of meetings.
The following key issues reflected to the revised draft SPA Law in relation to CCA:
-Local protected areas are part of the national protected areas’ network
-In addition to government, it’s proposed collaborative and community management governance types for both state and local protected areas.
4.A comprehensive feasibility study on current legal framework for community conservation areas and proposal of revisions/amendments to key legislations, including Law on Special Protected Areas, Environmental Protection Law and Law on Land .The study result has given practical basis to legitimize the community conservation areas to become an effective part of Mongolia's National protected areas system and allowing for community-based conservation management

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of community conservation areas legally recognized as part of the NPA system according to the amended national legislation and/or regulation

baseline.comment: 0 community conservation areas legally recognized as part of the NPA system

target.comment: 50 community conservation areas legally recognized as part of the NPA system

actual.comment: 30 community groups, of which 15 newly established, with total area of 340000 ha officially recognized and contracted with the soum governor for taking management responsibility over land and biodiversity in target 3 LPAs. By March 2015, a total of 1629 community conservation areas (8.2 mln. hectare) are recorded throughout the country with user rights over forest, wildlife, water and pasture resources.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Emplacement of institutional capacity and resource base development to ensure sustainability of Managed Resource PAs

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: METT Scores for at least three LPAs converted and/or established as community conservation areas

baseline.comment:
Need METT scores for three pilot sites:
Gulzat LPA 36
Khavtgar 26
Tumenkhaan-Shalz LPA 22

target.comment:
Each baseline METT score increased to:
Gulzat LPA 50
Khavtgar 40
Tumenkhaan-Shalz LPA 26

actual.comment: METT will be reapplied at project mid-term.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: PAAD has a fully functional, staffed and government funded community conservation area resource center providing on-going monitoring, support and extension training for local conservation decision-makers

baseline.comment: 0 functional institutional center within PAAD to support effective community conservation areas

target.comment: 1 functional institutional center within PAAD to support effective community conservation areas

actual.comment: 1 resource person within PAAD is under recruitment to oversee CCAs at national level

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Decentralised regional PA governance framework involving community and local governments (Soum and Aimag) established in 3 demonstration sites

baseline.comment:
0 project sites applying legally enforceable management plan to improve conservation of wide-ranging species and mitigate conservation threats
0 effective conservation management at regional level

target.comment:
3 project sites applying legally enforceable management plan to improve conservation of wide-ranging species and mitigate conservation threats
3 effective conservation management model developed in project target sites: Khavtgar, Gulzat, Tumenkhaan-Shalz LPA (as center of excellence)

actual.comment:
3 project sites applying legally enforceable management plan to improve conservation of wide-ranging species and mitigate conservation threats
3 effective conservation management model developed in project target sites: Khavtgar, Gulzat, Tumenkhaan-Shalz LPA s. In Gulzat an NGO is mandated by the local government for the management of the Gulzat LPA. In Tumenkhaan-Shalz LPA, a joint Management council (consisting representatives of stakeholders from all three soums) is established for the management of this LPA. In Khavtgar, the local government decided the LPA will have a status of a “state–owned company”, while a full time manager will be recruited.
The following common strategic documents were approved by the local government and operational in three project areas: Mid-term Strategic Plan (2015-2025); Management Plan (2015-2019) and Hunting Management Plan (2015-2016).
Specifically for ‘Tumenkhaan-Shalz’ LPA:
-Livestock sustainable development programme along with Livestock offset regulation has been developed for all 3 soums and approved by local government.
-The following standardized forms and templates for efficient management of CCAs are developed and utilized: Model bylaws for community management organizations, Model Terms of references of key officers, Model management and business plans for LPAs, model resolutions of local government.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Policing and enforcement of laws and regulations for biodiversity conservation results in reduction of threats and no net loss of key indicators at three pilot sites

baseline.comment:
Gulzat LPA:
Total population of Argali Sheep Ovis ammon ammon (1,048 as of 2012)
Total household number involved in community groups: 60% of total household number at Gulzat LPA
Khavtgar LPA:
Population of moose Alces alces (20 as of 2010)
Population of musk deer Moschus moschiferus (7 as of 2010)
Population of red deer Cervus elaphus (22 as of 2010)
Tumenkhaan-Shalz LPA:
No. of protected wetlands/lakes as habitat for key migratory bird species (0)
Mongolian Gazelle Habitat fragmented and/or migratory route not protected

target.comment:
Gulzat LPA:
Increase in population of Argali Sheep Ovis ammon ammon (1,150)
Total household number involved in community conservation increased: 50% of non-conservation community group household additionally involved in community groups for conservation
Khavtgar LPA:
Increase in population of moose Alces alces (25)
Increase in population of musk deer Moschus moschiferus (15)
Increase in population of red deer Cervus elaphus (30)
Tumenkhaan-Shalz LPA:
No. of protected wetlands/lakes, as habitat for key migratory bird species (5)
Mongolian Gazelle habitat protected through establishment of linkages and migratory routes with clear regulatory mechanism (regulation, # of decrees of aimag government) for conservation

actual.comment:
Gulzat LPA:
Increase in population of Argali Sheep Ovis ammon ammon (1,541)
Total household number involved in community conservation increased: 25% of non-conservation community group household additionally involved in community groups for conservation
Khavtgar LPA:
Baseline population of moose Alces alces (20)
Baseline population of musk deer Moschus moschiferus (7)
Baseline population of red deer Cervus elaphus (22)
Tumenkhaan-Shalz LPA:
No. of protected wetlands/lakes, as habitat for key migratory bird species (9)
Study on identifying connectivity and migratory areas for Gazelle, Argali sheep, demoiselle crane and forest ungulates is ongoing to be completed in September
